description: Ultimately from Latin deambulare, deambulatum; de- + ambulare (“to walk”). The medical sense is likely a new denominal from deambulation or by translation from Romance languages such as French déambuler and Italian deambulare.

verbs.description: deambulate (third-person singular simple present deambulates, present participle deambulating, simple past and past participle deambulated)

entries.meaning: (rare) To go out walking; to stroll.
(medicine) To walk independently, especially in contrast to a state where one is physically unable to walk.
